channel.title: A few questions about transformers
channel.description:
I want to step up my mains voltage (240V) to a few thousand so I can make sparks, and I need to make a transformer ye? All I know about transformers is that the ratio of coils on the primary to secondary is equal to the ratio at which the emf is stepped up (or down).
If the ratio between the numbers of coils on the primary and secondary is kept constant but the overall number of coils is decreased, what effect does this have? Using simple theory it has no effect, but it must have some effect in practice. Is the transformer more efficient with more coils?
I'm also wondering what happens if the emf is connected across the primary coil, but there is no load on the secondary coil. Is the energy wasted as heat by magnetostriction or an increased flow of eddy currents or something?
I have the transformer coil out of an ancient radio, but by passing some current through it I found that it only steps up by a ratio of 1:3. I thought I could unwind some of the primary coil, so the ratio is higher and so I get a higher output emf, but I doubt it's this easy and I don't want to destroy my only transformer =[ Would this work?
If it makes a difference, both coils are wound together in one core instead of the usual two core thing you see in gcse books. It's kind of like this (the yellow thing), only much bigger and you can actually see the coils: http://www.precision-inc.com/appnotes/images/rdr157.jpg
